message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical findings are consistent with infectious mononucleosis, including the palpable spleen and hepatomegaly, and the blood smear morphology of atypical lymphocytes. Cytomegalovirus infection can have similar symptoms but typically doesn't cause hepatosplenomegaly. Graves' disease is unlikely in a 7-year-old and viral hepatitis doesn't have the same blood smear morphology.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including sore throat, fever, and palpable spleen, along with the blood smear showing abnormal lymphocytes with blue-gray cytoplasm and irregular nuclei, suggest infectious mononucleosis. The other options do not fit with the presented symptoms and findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and blood smear findings suggest infectious mononucleosis, which is caused by the Epstein-Barr virus. Cytomegalovirus infection may have similar symptoms but the blood smear findings are usually different. Graves' disease and viral hepatitis are not likely to cause these symptoms and blood smear findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including sore throat and fever, and the blood smear findings suggest infectious mononucleosis. Other options do not match the symptoms or blood smear findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination (diffuse white exudate on both tonsils, palpable spleen with mild hepatomegaly, large and abundant lymphocytes with blue-gray cytoplasm, irregular nuclei, and dark chromatin with inconspicuous nucleoli) are consistent with Infectious mononucleosis. All other options do not explain the physical examination and blood smear results.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described are consistent with infectious mononucleosis, including the presence of white exudate on both tonsils and a palpable spleen. The blood smear also shows atypical lymphocytes, which are characteristic of infectious mononucleosis. None of the other options are likely to cause these symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of sore throat, fever, and enlarged spleen suggest infectious mononucleosis, which is further confirmed by the characteristic large lymphocytes seen on the blood smear. The other options do not fit with the patient's symptoms and laboratory findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including sore throat, fever, and splenomegaly, point towards infectious mononucleosis. The blood smear findings of large and abundant lymphocytes with blue-gray cytoplasm and irregular nuclei confirm the diagnosis. None of the other options match the symptoms and blood smear findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of sore throat, fever, malaise, and lymphocytosis suggest infectious mononucleosis. The presence of diffuse white exudate and palpable spleen with mild hepatomegaly are also common findings in infectious mononucleosis. None of the other options match the symptoms and laboratory findings described.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and blood smear findings suggest infectious mononucleosis, which is caused by the Epstein-Barr virus. Cytomegalovirus infection may cause similar symptoms, but the blood smear findings are different. Graves’ disease and viral hepatitis do not typically present with sore throat or lymphocytosis.
